class_notes:
What is a history picture?  In art theoretical writing, the nexus amongst invention, imitation, and the historia, far from being treated as self-evident, was subject to constant revision.  What do these texts and related images they tell us about the nexus between historical invention and ordonnance, between evidentiary history and fictional poetry, between the historical scopus (center of interest) and its ornaments, between history and the other pictorial genres? 
This is an upper-level, writing-intensive seminar designed for students who have some experience with art history, typically having taken courses at the 200 or 300 level.
Art History major/minor: Division II
Class will meet at The Fox Center (1635 North Decatur Road) Room 101.
course_description: Advanced seminar with emphasis on critical texts, methods, and techniques of art historical investigation. For art history majors; open to others with permission from the instructor.
